description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Den föreslagna insatsen har till syfte att bidra till den pågående stabiliserings- och statsbyggnadsprocessen i Somalia genom att tillvarata den kompetens och kunskap som finns hos den somaliska diasporan. Insatsen skall förstärka kapaciteten hos viktiga ministerier och institutioner. Den har fokus på stöd till statens kärnfunktioner som är avgörande för att Somalia skall uppnå sina mål som anges i den nationella utvecklingsplanen. Sida har sedan 2013 finansierat program för sekondering av somalisk diaspora (akademiker) till en rad institutioner i Somalia, genomfört av International Organization for Migration (IOM). Sekonderingen har skett till institutioner på federal och delstatsnivå.
Den andra fasen av programmet "Stärka den somaliska institutionella kapaciteten genom diaspora" kommer att implementeras av Nordic International Support Foundation (NIS). NIS är en norska ideell organisation (NGO) med huvudkontor i Oslo, Norge, med landskontor i Somalia, Mali och Myanmar. NIS är en samarbetspart till Sida i Myanmar sedan 2015 och har bl.a. implementerat den givargemensam fonden ”Peace Support Fund (PSF)”.
Den nya fasen kommer att bygga vidare på fas 1 av det tidigare stödet och kommer att fortsätta prioritera statliga institutioner i syfte att stärka den institutionella kapaciteten hos prioriterade institutioner som har viktiga funktioner i statsbyggnaden i Somalia, inklusive stärkande val- och konstitutionella processer samt en fungerande federal modell i Somalia.
De sektorer och institutioner som skall prioriteras i den nya fasen av programmet inkluderar; hälsa, rättvisa, offentlig finansiell styrning, mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet, planering, statistik, utrikes- och internationellt samarbete, konstitutionsöversynen och val samt president och premiärminister kontoren. Det nya programmet kommer även fortsatt stödja kapacitetsutveckling för ministeriet för humanitära frågor och katastrofhantering. Diaspora experterna kommer också att sekonderas till institutionerna på delstatsnivå.

Institutional capacity building intervention targeting the identified key Somali institutions is critical for Somalia to successfully achieve its reconstruction and development objectives stipulated in the National Development Plan. Sida has been supporting the secondment of high-capacity Somali Diaspora to a range of institutions in Somalia since 2013. This work has sought to support the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) in the implementation of the Somali National Development Plan (NDP), as well as institutional capacity development more broadly. The second phase of the program "Strengthening Somali Institutional Capacity through Diaspora" will be implemented by the Nordic International Support Foundation (NIS). This will build on phase 1 of the previous support and will continue prioritizing government institutions such as good governance and strengthening the electoral and constitutional processes as well as functioning federal model of Somalia.
The targeted sectors includes but is not limited to :Justice and constitution, Health and Public Financial Management, Gender and Human Right, Planning, Statistics, Foreign Affairs and international Cooperation as well as the office of the President and the office of the Prime Minister. The project will also continue to support the Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs and Disaster Management. The Diaspora experts will also be seconded to the federal and member states institutions.

description.narrative: Due global effects of the Covid-19 pandemic after the end of the first quarter of 2020, all activities were put on hold. Sida has approved a request from FGS in regards to Covid-19 pandemic effects. Therefore, parts of the funds under the programme were re-directed towards support in combating the Covid-19 pandemic effects. Subsequently, the programme budget was revised accordingly. NIS recruited for a period of 4 months, additional 16 experts to support the FGS, all FMS and Somaliland in the Covid-19 coordination and response efforts. Additional 64 health volunteers to support Covid-19 response in designated institutions and call centers in all FMS, BRA and SL were supported. Since the programme started in August 2019, a total of 23 experts (local and from the diaspora) have been seconded by the programme for period ranging from 2 to 19 months. Twelve (12) government institutions at the FGS and FMS have benefitted from the support of these experts. The findings of the assessments conducted by NIS at the initial stage of the programme revealed that, the institutional gaps at the FGS and the FMS were vast and thus motivated consultations between Sida and the OPM office representing the Government of Somalia. Thus, Sida and OPM embarked on identifying the most critical and crucial institutions that were consistent with Sida’s support priorities. The consultations between OPM and Sida delayed when the Covid-19 pandemic affected Somalia. This also delayed the prioritization of FGS institutions that were to be supported. Due to the pandemic response, priorities of the programme changed, including that most programme activities planned for 2020 had to be rescheduled. The Institutional Capacity and Needs Assessment conducted by NIS at the initial stage of the programme ascertains limited achievements in addressing the long-term capacity development of Somali institutions. The Government of Somalia is to a large extent run and sustained by technical experts, seconded and paid by development partners, whose exit can have drastic and significant effects on the Government´s capacity and ability to function. However, lack of strong government leadership, weak human resource and performance systems, weak inter-agency and donor coordination and governance structures poses significant challenges to success of capacity building programme. The lack of a National Public Sector Reform Strategy to provide the framework for long-term capacity development programming and systematic implementation of interventions by both Government and Development Partners hampers long term capacity development in Somalia. Moreover, unclarities on the mandates and functions across federal government institutions has been an obstacle to establishing credible institutions that fulfil core government functions and improve service delivery. As part of addressing these challenges and better coordination among development partners, the UN has developed a Capacity Injection Reporting Tool (CIRT). The CIRT is a tool for sharing information about financial support for professional staff embedded in government on long-term contracts. CIRT is managed by the UN Resident Coordinator's Office (RCO) and Risk Management Unit (RMU). The cooperation partner reports to CIRT. The cooperation partner has designed and developed database that contains necessary information such as skills set and other variables deemed useful for managing the programme effectively.
